TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Fine-silty, mixed, superactive, mesic Xeric Haplargids

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON: Heydlauff silt loam--on a 1 percent slope at 4,500 feet in rangeland. (Color is for dry soil unless otherwise noted. When described on April 29, 1980 the soil was dry to 5 inches and moist below.)
A1--0 to 2 inches; pale brown (10YR 6/3) silt loam, dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) moist; moderate fine platy structure; soft, very friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; many fine and few medium roots; many fine tubular pores; moderately alkaline (pH 7.9); abrupt smooth boundary.
A2--2 to 5 inches; pale brown (10YR 6/3) silt loam, dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) moist; moderate medium and fine platy structure; soft, very friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; many fine and few medium roots; many fine tubular pores; moderately alkaline (pH 8.0); abrupt smooth boundary. (combined thickness of the A horizon is 2 to 8 inches)
Btk--5 to 11 inches; light brownish gray (10YR 6/2) silty clay loam, dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) moist; moderate medium prismatic structure parting to strong fine subangular blocky; very hard, firm, sticky and plastic; few distinct clay films on faces of peds and in pores; common fine roots; common fine tubular pores; strong effervescence; moderately alkaline (pH 8.2); clear smooth boundary. (4 to 7 inches thick)
Bk--11 to 13 inches; very pale brown (10YR 7/4) silty clay loam, dark yellowish brown (10YR 4/4) moist; moderate fine subangular blocky structure; very hard, firm, sticky and plastic; few fine roots; few fine tubular pores; violent effervescence; moderately alkaline (pH 8.3); clear smooth boundary. (2 to 6 inches thick)
C1--13 to 37 inches; very pale brown (10YR 7/4) silt loam, very pale brown (10YR 7/3) moist; massive; slightly hard, friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; few fine roots; few fine tubular pores; slight effervescence; moderately alkaline (pH 8.3); clear wavy boundary.  (20 to 30 inches thick)
C2--37 to 48 inches; light gray (2.5Y 7/2) silt loam, light brownish gray (2.5Y 6/2) moist; massive; slightly hard, friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; few fine roots; few fine tubular pores; slight effervescence; moderately alkaline (pH 8.2) gradual wavy boundary. (10 to 15 inches thick)
C3--48 to 60 inches; pale brown (10YR 6/3) silt loam, brown (10YR 5/3) moist; massive; slightly hard, friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; few fine tubular pores; slight effervescence; moderately alkaline (pH 8.2)).

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION: Oneida County, Idaho; about 1/2 mile west of Stone, Idaho, about 1,400 feet east and 150 feet south of the northwest corner of section 27, T.16S., R.32E.  Latitude - 42 degrees, 50 seconds North; Longitude - 112 degrees, 42 minutes, 30 seconds West.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:
Depth to secondary lime - 2 to 8 inches
Average annual soil temperature - 48 to 50 degrees F. Average summer soil temperature - 63 to 67 degrees F. Control section averages - 27 to 34 percent clay
A horizon
Value - 3 or 4 moist
Btk horizon
Value - 6 or 7 dry, 4 or 5 moist
Chroma - 2 or 3 dry or moist
Bk horizon
Value - 7 or 8 dry, 4 or 5 moist
Chroma - 2 through 4 dry or moist
Reaction - moderately or strongly alkaline
Calcium carbonate equivalent - 5 to 15 percent
C horizon
Hue - 10YR or 2.5Y
Value - 6 or 7 dry, 5 through 7 moist
Chroma - 2 through 4 dry or moist
Reaction - moderately or strongly alkaline
Calcium carbonate equivalent - 5 to 15 percent

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES: These are the Greenleaf, Hansel, McCain and Power series. Greenleaf, Hansel and Power soils are deeper than 10 inches to secondary lime. Greenleaf soils have average annual soils temperature higher than 51 degrees F. and have strong platy structure in the Bk horizon. McCain soils are 20 to 40 inches to bedrock.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING: Heydlauff soils are on lacustrine terraces at elevations of 4,400 to 4,600 feet.  They formed in lake sediments from ancient Lake Bonneville.  Slopes are 0 to 2 percent.  The average annual precipitation ranges from 9 to 11 inches.  The average annual air temperature is 46 to 48 degrees F.  The frost free period is 100 to 120 days.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Bahem, Hans, Mellor, Tickason and Thiokol soils.  These are adjacent soils on ancient Lake Bonneville terraces. Bahem, Hans, Tickason, and Thiokol soils lack an argillic horizon. Mellor soils have a natric horizon.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY: Well drained. Slow runoff.  Slow permeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  Irrigated cropland and rangeland. Major crops include wheat, barley and alfalfa hay. The native vegetation is basin big sagebrush, bluebunch wheatgrass, streambank wheatgrass, and arrowleaf balsamroot.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Southeastern Idaho.  These soils are not extensive.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Davis, California

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:  Diagnostic horizons and features recognized in this pedon are:
Ochric epipedon - The zone from 0 to 5 inches (A1 and A2 horizons)
Argillic horizon - The zone from 5 to 11 inches (Btk horizon)
Particle-size control section (Argillic Horizon) - The zone from 5 to 11 inches (Btk horizon).
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U.S.A.
